review.title: An overview of embedding models of entities and relationships for knowledge base completion
review.abstract: Knowledge bases of real-world facts about entities and their relationships are useful resources for a variety of natural language processing tasks. However, because knowledge bases are typically incomplete, it is useful to be able to perform knowledge base completion, i.e., predict whether a relationship not in the knowledge base is likely to be true. This article presents an overview of embedding models of entities and relationships for knowledge base completion, with up-to-date experimental results on two standard evaluation tasks of link prediction (i.e. entity prediction) and triple classification.
histories: 8 pages, 4 tables. arXiv admin note: substantial text overlap witharXiv:1606.06461,arXiv:1606.08140

v1: 8 pages, 4 tables; v2: Update results for RESCAL (Nickel et al., 2011) and ComplEx (Trouillon et al., 2016). arXiv admin note: substantial text overlap witharXiv:1606.08140; text overlap witharXiv:1606.06461
review.COMMENTS: 8 pages, 4 tables. arXiv admin note: substantial text overlap witharXiv:1606.06461,arXiv:1606.08140

metadata.title: An overview of embedding models of entities and relationships for knowledge base completion

sections.text: Keywords: completion of the knowledge base, link prediction, embedding model, triple classification, entity prediction.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Knowledge databases (KBs) such as WordNet (Miller, 1995), YAGO (Suchanek et al., 2007), Freebase (Bollacker et al., 2008) and DBpedia (Lehmann et al., 2015) represent relationships between entities as triples (head-entity, relationship, tail entity) Even very large knowledge databases are far from complete (Socher et al., 2013; West et al., 2014). Knowledge-based completion or linkage systems (Nickel al., 2016a) predict which triples are not likely to be true in a knowledge database (Taskar et al., 2004; Bordes et al., 2011). Embedding models for KB completions associate entities and / or relationships with dense feature vectors or matrices. Such models maintain state-of-theart performance (Bordes et al., 2013; Guu et al., 2015; Nyen et al.

sections.heading: 2 Embedding models for KB completion
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 2.1 General idea
sections.text: Use G to indicate the knowledge base, which consists of a set of correct triples (h, r, t) of their implausibility. Your goal is to select f so that the score f (h, r, t) of a plausible triple (h, r, t) is smaller than the score f (h, r, t) of an implausible triple (h, r, t). Table 1 summarizes various score functions f (h, r, t) and the optimization algorithms for estimating model parameters, e.g. Vanilla Stochastic Descent (SGD), SGD + AdaGrad (Duchi et al., 2011), SGD + AdaDelta (Zeiler, 2012) and FcS function (B function).

sections.heading: 2.2 Specific models
sections.text: The model Structured Embedding (SE) (Bordes et al., 2011) extends the unstructured model by assuming that the head and tail entities are similar only in a relationship-dependent subspace in which each relationship is represented by two different matrices. Futhermore, the model SME (Bordes et al., 2012) uses four different matrices to project entity and relationship to a subspace. The TransE model (Bordes et al., 2013) is inspired by models such as the model Word2Vec Skipgram et al., 2013), in which relationships between words often correspond with latent characteristics.

sections.heading: 3 Evaluation tasks
sections.text: Two standard tasks are proposed to evaluate the embedding of models to complete KB, including: the task of predicting entities, i.e. the link prediction (Bordes et al., 2013), and the task of triple classification (Socher et al., 2013). Usually, the WN18 and FB15k (Bordes et al., 2013) data sets are used to predict entities, while the WN11 and FB13 data sets (Socher et al., 2013) are used for triple classification. WN18 and WN11 are derived from the large lexical KB WordNet (Miller, 1995). FB15k and FB13 are derived from the large real fact KB FreeBase (Bollacker et al., 2008).

sections.heading: 3.1 Entity prediction
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 3.1.1 Task description
sections.text: The predictive task of the entity, i.e. the link prediction (Bordes et al., 2013), predicts the head or tail entity with respect to the transformation type and the other entity, i.e. the prediction of h given (?, r, t) or the prediction of t given (h, r,?), where? denotes the missing entity. Results are evaluated on the basis of a ranking induced by the function f (h, r, t) on test triplets. Any correct test triple (h, r, t) is corrupted by replacing either the head or tail entity with each of the possible entities, and then these candidates are ranked in ascending order of their implausibility value. This is referred to as the "Raw" setting protocol. Furthermore, the "filtered" setting protocol described in Bordes et al. (2013) is listed in the triple ranking order of each KB, the triple ranking of the entrant.

sections.heading: 3.1.2 Main results
sections.text: Table 3 lists the entity prediction results of KB completion models on the WN18 and FB15k datasets; the first 18 lines show the performance of models that do not evaluate alternative paths between header and tail entities; the next 5 lines show the results of models that evaluate information on relation paths; the last 3 lines show results for models that do not evaluate textual mentions coming from a large external body; it is clear that the models with the additional external body information achieved the best results; Table 3 also shows that models that use path information generally achieve better results than models that do not use such information. In terms of models that do not evaluate path information or external information, the ComplEx model achieves the highest values on FB15k. Furthermore, the STransE model performs better than its closely related models SE, TransE, TransR, CR, CR, Transk, and F18 on both NBD and Spark.

sections.heading: 3.2 Triple classification
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 3.2.1 Task description
sections.text: The triple classification task was first introduced by Socher et al. (2013) and has since been used to evaluate various embedding models. The aim of this task is to predict whether a triple (h, r, t) is correct or not. A relation-specific threshold is specified for each relationship type r. If the implausibility value of an invisible test triple (h, r, t) is lower than θr, then the triple is classified as right, otherwise as wrong. According to Socher et al. (2013), the relation-specific thresholds are determined on the validation theorem by maximizing the micro-averaged accuracy, which is a triple average.

sections.heading: 3.2.2 Main results
sections.text: Table 4 presents the triple classification results of KB completion models on the WN11 and FB13 datasets. The first 6 lines report the performance of models that use TransE to initialize the entity and the relation vectors.The last 11 lines show the accuracy of models with randomly initialized parameters. Note that there are higher results1 In fact, TransE achieves very competitive performance in entity forecasting and triple classification tasks, as shown in Tables 3 and 4. This is due to a careful web search. For NTN, Bilinear-COMP and TransECOMP reported when entity vectors (2015), Lin et al. (2015), Lin et al. (2015a) and Garcı � aDura � n et al. (2016) are initialized by averaging the pre-formed word vectors (Mikolov et al., Pennington; et al., 2014).

sections.heading: 4 Conclusions and further discussion
sections.text: This article gave an overview of the embedding of entity models and relationships for completion of KB. The article also provided current experimental results of the embedding models for entity prediction and triple classification. It would be interesting to further investigate these models for a new application where triple data is available. For example, Vu et al. (2017) extended the STransE model (Nguyen et al., 2016b) for the search personalization task in information retrieval to model a user-oriented relationship between query and document.

This article serves as a brief overview of embedding models for KB completion, with up-to-date experimental results on two standard evaluation tasks: i) the entity prediction task—which is also referred to as the link prediction task (Bordes et al., 2013)—and ii) the
triple classification task (Socher et al., 2013).

The Unstructured model (Bordes et al., 2012) assumes that the head and tail entity vectors are similar.

The Structured Embedding (SE) model (Bordes et al., 2011) extends the Unstructured model by assuming that the head and tail entities are similar only in a relation-dependent subspace, where each relation is represented by two different matrices.
Futhermore, the SME model (Bordes et al., 2012) uses four different matrices to project entity and relation vectors into a subspace.
The TransE model (Bordes et al., 2013) is inspired by models such as the Word2Vec Skipgram model (Mikolov et al.

The TransH model (Wang et al., 2014) associates each relation with a relation-specific hyperplane and uses a projection vector to project entity vectors onto that hyperplane.

(2015) showed that using these pre-trained vectors for initialization helps to improve the performance of the TransE (Bordes et al., 2013), SME (Bordes et al., 2012) and SE (Bordes et al., 2011). In addition, Liang and Forbus (2015) used the implausibility score produced by SME to compute the weights of relation paths.
Furthermore, RTransE (Garcı́a-Durán et al., 2015), PTransE (Lin et al.
, 2015a) and TransECOMP (Guu et al., 2015) are extensions of the TransE model.

These models similarly represent a relation path by a vector which is the sum of the vectors of all relations in the path, whereas in the Bilinear-COMP model (Guu et al., 2015) and the PRUNED-PATHS model (Toutanova et al.
, 2015) and the PRUNED-PATHS model (Toutanova et al., 2016), each relation is a matrix and so it represents the relation path by matrix multiplication.

Furthermore, RTransE (Garcı́a-Durán et al., 2015), PTransE (Lin et al., 2015a) and TransECOMP (Guu et al., 2015) are extensions of the TransE model. These models similarly represent a relation path by a vector which is the sum of the vectors of all relations in the path, whereas in the Bilinear-COMP model (Guu et al., 2015) and the PRUNED-PATHS model (Toutanova et al., 2016), each relation is a matrix and so it represents the relation path by matrix multiplication. The neighborhood mixture model TransE-NMM (Nguyen et al., 2016a) can be also viewed as a three-relation path model as it takes into account the neighborhood entity and relation information of both head and tail entities in each triple. Other relation path-based models: The Path Ranking Algorithm (PRA) (Lao and Cohen, 2010) is a random walk inference technique which was proposed to predict a new relationship between two entities in KBs. Lao et al. (2011) used PRA to estimate the probability of an unseen triple as a combination of weighted random walks that follow different paths linking the head entity and tail entity in the KB.

Furthermore, RTransE (Garcı́a-Durán et al., 2015), PTransE (Lin et al., 2015a) and TransECOMP (Guu et al., 2015) are extensions of the TransE model. These models similarly represent a relation path by a vector which is the sum of the vectors of all relations in the path, whereas in the Bilinear-COMP model (Guu et al., 2015) and the PRUNED-PATHS model (Toutanova et al., 2016), each relation is a matrix and so it represents the relation path by matrix multiplication. The neighborhood mixture model TransE-NMM (Nguyen et al., 2016a) can be also viewed as a three-relation path model as it takes into account the neighborhood entity and relation information of both head and tail entities in each triple. Other relation path-based models: The Path Ranking Algorithm (PRA) (Lao and Cohen, 2010) is a random walk inference technique which was proposed to predict a new relationship between two entities in KBs. Lao et al. (2011) used PRA to estimate the probability of an unseen triple as a combination of weighted random walks that follow different paths linking the head entity and tail entity in the KB. Gardner et al. (2014) made use of an external text corpus to increase the connectivity of the KB used as the input to PRA.

Furthermore, RTransE (Garcı́a-Durán et al., 2015), PTransE (Lin et al., 2015a) and TransECOMP (Guu et al., 2015) are extensions of the TransE model. These models similarly represent a relation path by a vector which is the sum of the vectors of all relations in the path, whereas in the Bilinear-COMP model (Guu et al., 2015) and the PRUNED-PATHS model (Toutanova et al., 2016), each relation is a matrix and so it represents the relation path by matrix multiplication. The neighborhood mixture model TransE-NMM (Nguyen et al., 2016a) can be also viewed as a three-relation path model as it takes into account the neighborhood entity and relation information of both head and tail entities in each triple. Other relation path-based models: The Path Ranking Algorithm (PRA) (Lao and Cohen, 2010) is a random walk inference technique which was proposed to predict a new relationship between two entities in KBs. Lao et al. (2011) used PRA to estimate the probability of an unseen triple as a combination of weighted random walks that follow different paths linking the head entity and tail entity in the KB. Gardner et al. (2014) made use of an external text corpus to increase the connectivity of the KB used as the input to PRA. Gardner and Mitchell (2015) improved PRA by proposing a subgraph feature extraction technique to make the generation of random walks in KBs more efficient and expressive, while Wang et al.

Furthermore, RTransE (Garcı́a-Durán et al., 2015), PTransE (Lin et al., 2015a) and TransECOMP (Guu et al., 2015) are extensions of the TransE model. These models similarly represent a relation path by a vector which is the sum of the vectors of all relations in the path, whereas in the Bilinear-COMP model (Guu et al., 2015) and the PRUNED-PATHS model (Toutanova et al., 2016), each relation is a matrix and so it represents the relation path by matrix multiplication. The neighborhood mixture model TransE-NMM (Nguyen et al., 2016a) can be also viewed as a three-relation path model as it takes into account the neighborhood entity and relation information of both head and tail entities in each triple. Other relation path-based models: The Path Ranking Algorithm (PRA) (Lao and Cohen, 2010) is a random walk inference technique which was proposed to predict a new relationship between two entities in KBs. Lao et al. (2011) used PRA to estimate the probability of an unseen triple as a combination of weighted random walks that follow different paths linking the head entity and tail entity in the KB. Gardner et al. (2014) made use of an external text corpus to increase the connectivity of the KB used as the input to PRA. Gardner and Mitchell (2015) improved PRA by proposing a subgraph feature extraction technique to make the generation of random walks in KBs more efficient and expressive, while Wang et al. (2016) extended PRA to couple the path ranking of multiple relations.
model (Niepert, 2016).
In addition, Neelakantan et al. (2015) used a recurrent neural network to learn vector representations of PRA-style relation paths between entities in the KB.

The similar observation is also found by Garcı́a-Durán et al. (2015), Lin et al. (2015a) and Garcı́aDurán et al. (2016). The reason is due to a careful grid search. reported for NTN, Bilinear-COMP and TransECOMP when entity vectors are initialized by averaging the pre-trained word vectors (Mikolov et al., 2013; Pennington et al., 2014). It is not surprising as many entity names in WordNet and FreeBase are lexically meaningful. It is possible for all other embedding models to utilize the pre-trained word vectors as well. However, as pointed out by Wang et al. (2014) and Guu et al. (2015), averaging the pre-trained word vectors for initializing entity vectors is an open problem and it is not always useful since entity names in many domain-specific KBs are not lexically meaningful.

metadata.abstractText: Knowledge bases of real-world facts about entities and their relationships are useful resources for a variety of natural language processing tasks. However, because knowledge bases are typically incomplete, it is useful to be able to perform knowledge base completion or link prediction, i.e., predict whether a relationship not in the knowledge base is likely to be true. This article presents an overview of embedding models of entities and relationships for knowledge base completion.
